section.title: Records
section.para: A recordrecord is an unordered finite map from keykeys to values. The empty record is written as {. .}.

section.title: Constructors
section.para: A record is constructed from a comma-separated sequence of bindings enclosed by dotted braces. Each binding associates a key with an expression.
Duplicate bindings for the same key are allowed, but only the rightmost binding will be used in the resulting record value.

section.title: Operations
section.para:
Notable record operations include:
R.key, a dotdot access, which publishes the value bound to key in R. If R has no binding for key, R.key halts silently.
R + S, a record extensionrecord extension, which publishes a new record with all of the bindings of S, plus all of the bindings in R which do not bind keys mentioned in S. In other words, S overrides R.
Record extension is associative, but not commutative. The expression {. K0 = E0 , … , Kn = En .} is equivalent to the expression {. K0 = E0 .} + … + {. Kn = En .}.

section.title: Special Keys
section.para: There are two record keys that have special meanings:

listitem.para: If a record has a binding for the applyapply key, then the record may be called like a site or function.
If a record has a binding for the unapplyunapply key, then the record may be used in a call pattern.

Java calls
section.para: Orc records do not correspond to any Java value, so if a record is passed to Java code, it will be as a java.lang.Object of a type not specified here.
